Title:
Why Are Red Flowers So Rare? Testing the Macroevolutionary
Causes of Tippiness
Keywords:
diversification, evolutionary dead end, extinction, flower
color, HiSSE, Solanaceae, trait evolution, transition rate
Abstract:
Traits that have arisen multiple times yet still remain
rare present a curious paradox. A number of these rare traits show a
distinct tippy pattern, where they appear widely dispersed across a
phylogeny, are concentrated along the tips of short branches, and often
do not have the same trait state as their sister species. This
phylogenetic pattern has classically been attributed to the trait being
an evolutionary dead end, where the trait arose due to some short-term
evolutionary advantage, but it ultimately leads species to extinction.
While the higher extinction rate associated with a dead end trait could
produce such a tippy pattern, a similar pattern could have also arisen
if lineages with the trait speciated slower than other lineages, or if
the trait was lost more often that it was gained. In this study, we
investigate the macroevolutionary processes that best explain the rare
and tippy distribution of red flowers in the Solanaceae family. We test
16 alternative models using HiSSE, which allows the inclusion of models
with multiple diversification rates. We found the best model to be one
where lineages with red flowers exhibit reduced diversification rates
due to elevated extinction rates and a bias towards loss of red flowers.
These results suggest that red Solanaceae flowers are rare and tippy due
to a combination of processes, including being an evolutionary dead
end.
